Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Proposal: Millipede Systematics: Developing phylogenomic, classification, and taxonomic resources for the future
Award.AbstractNarration:
The arthropod class Diplopoda (the millipedes) comprises ~12,000 described species that are distributed worldwide in nearly every biome. The group has a deep evolutionary history that includes some of the very first terrestrial animals, dating from the mid-Silurian over 400 million years ago. Despite their ecological importance as decomposers in forests, wealth of diversity (estimated 20,000-80,000 species), and prominence as chemical warriors owing to their vast array of defense secretions, the group is woefully understudied. The research team will revise the current ordinal and family-level classification systems using a modern phylogenomic framework based on next generation sequence data and then employ these data to explore the evolution of chemical defense secretions and their precursors.

This project seeks to greatly enhance the accessibility of millipede diversity through the development of a morphological atlas for the group, production of the first illustrated key to millipede families, and publication of the first complete millipede species catalog. The project team will develop a strong collaborative research and training network and will partner with collaborators worldwide. Training in millipede systematics, morphology, and genomics will include a broad range of individuals from high school students and teachers, undergraduate researchers, a postdoctoral trainee, to students participating in organized training workshops, to be held in the Southeastern US and in Bangkok, Thailand.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The class Diplopoda, millipedes, are a species-rich group of arthropods that are among the most important decomposers in terrestrial ecosystems.  By feeding on decaying wood, detritus and leaf litter, millipedes help break-down dead vegetation freeing up essential nutrients that would otherwise be tied up in organic material. With 12,000 described species, they are found on all continents but Antarctica and in virtually all terrestrial biomes.  Current estimates place the actual number of species somewhere between 20,000 and 80,000, and many species remain undescribed.  Despite their diversity, abundance, and complex chemical ecology, the group remains woefully understudied. Taxonomically, millipedes have had a history of relative neglect; at any one period, no more than 3-6 specialists worldwide have worked on them, often in isolation. The major aim underlying this project was to advance solutions for central problems remaining in millipede systematics and resolve issues that may impede future progress in the field. First, the project resolved the higher-level evolutionary history of the group thereby providing a robust and stable classification scheme. Second, stemming from the lack of an evolutionary framework, we were interested in elucidating the evolution of the group’s complex defense chemicals.  These include many newly discovered compounds from phenols and quinones to alkaloids. Third, any student of millipedes is literally thwarted by the lack of taxonomic resources – namely the absence of a catalog to species; a principal aim of the project was to develop an online millipede taxonomic species catalog. The specific objectives of the project were to 1) Reconstruct the phylogeny of the class Diplopoda using RNA-Seq next generation sequencing data representing the majority of the millipede ordinal and family level diversity; 2) In coordination with field collecting to obtain fresh material for RNA extractions, obtain chemical secretion samples to evaluate their evolution within a phylogenetic context; 3) Develop an illustrated atlas to millipede morphology; and 4) Publish an online World Millipede Species Catalog. 

Our project team conducted extensive field work throughout the United States, Southern Africa, Central America, and Southeast Asia. In collaboration with colleagues at institutions throughout the world, we acquired over >2000 specimens representing a significant degree of millipede diversity. From these specimens we collected tissues for molecular phylogenetic studies, chemical extracts for gas chromatography and mass spectrometry analysis, and morphological study. The molecular phylogeny from our study is the most extensive published to date with respect to both species sampling and numbers of genes. Moreover, the evolution of chemical defense secretions has never been considered within the context of a robust phylogeny.  All but five millipede orders have repugnatorial glands that secrete chemical defenses when disturbed by predators. These complex mixtures of chemicals belong to at least eight molecule types (i.e., 1,4-benzoquinones, phenols, hydrogen cyanide, quinazolinones, and alkaloids) with the most complex chemical system within millipedes—in terms of diversity of chemical structure and associated anatomy—is found in Juliformia (ring-bearing millipedes) with the production of benzoquinones. As posited by us in a published paper, there is clearly a pattern of a positive directional increase in complexity of chemical manufacture over the course of millipede evolution. Our results definitively demonstrate that chemical complexity shows a clear pattern of escalation through time; that is, new chemical pathways are added in a stepwise pattern, leading to greater chemical complexity, independently in a number of derived lineages. This complexity in chemical defensive secretion structure gradually increased across millipede phylogeny, leading to the advent of three distantly related chemically complex evolutionary lineages, each uniquely characteristic of each of the respective millipede groups.

In addition to advancing the field of millipede molecular systematics, the team, led by Petra Sierwald at the Field Museum of Natural History, has developed the World Millipede Catalog – Millibase (http://www.millibase.org/). The online database provides an integral taxonomic resource that will likely serve the community for decades to come. The taxonomic editors collaborating on the project have as a goal to continuously update and improve the database to promote all forms of current and future millipede research and to support an active and vibrant global millipede research community.

Finally, the project has served to broadly impact the field and the community through student training (undergraduate and graduate students and a postdoctoral scholar) and dissemination of results through publications and guest talks and lectures. The project team presented multiple seminars and at numerous outreach events over the course of the duration of the grant: seminars at The Virginia Museum of Natural History, Department of Biology William and Mary, Department of Biological Sciences Auburn University, University of Nebraska Lincoln, University of California Davis, Virginia Tech Bugfest (multiple years), The Price House Nature Center (Blacksburg, VA), Auburn University Museum of Natural History Fall Open House (multiple years), Women’s Leadership Symposium (Auburn University), and other online sources (e.g., http://jointedlegs.org).
